questions.question: What does the poem compare to a spaceship? (Variant 51)
questions.answer: A snail is used as the opposite to show slowness.

questions.question: How do we know this poem focuses on opposites? (Variant 52)
questions.answer: Every line uses contrasting words like fast-slow, big-small.

questions.question: What are two items used to compare temperature? (Variant 53)
questions.answer: Warm as toast and cool as a cave show temperature.

questions.question: Why must compared things share a common feature? (Variant 54)
questions.answer: Otherwise the comparison becomes meaningless or confusing.

questions.question: Which comparison tells you something is soft? (Variant 55)
questions.answer: Soft as a mitten describes something gentle to touch.

questions.question: What is the meaning of ‘gentle as a lamb’? (Variant 56)
questions.answer: It means someone is mild and harmless like a lamb.

questions.question: Why might a poet choose animals for comparisons? (Variant 57)
questions.answer: Animals are familiar and help readers imagine qualities easily.

questions.answer: Big as a dinosaur and small as a nail show size.

questions.answer: Dark as a tunnel suggests complete or heavy darkness.

questions.question: Explain how the poem uses opposites to create strong imagery. (Insight 151)
questions.answer: Every line presents a pair of ideas that are far apart such as fast-slow or dry-wet. These opposites give the reader a strong sense of contrast and make everyday things exciting.

questions.question: Describe why similes help readers imagine things more clearly. (Insight 152)
questions.answer: Similes use familiar objects to describe unfamiliar or strong feelings. By saying 'strong as an ox', readers immediately understand the meaning without long explanations.

questions.question: How does the poet move from size and shape to sound and strength? (Insight 153)
questions.answer: The poem begins with size and speed, moves into taste, sound and strength, and ends with light-dark contrasts, showing many types of properties we can compare.

questions.question: Discuss why the poem says 'the world is full of opposites'. (Insight 154)
questions.answer: Opposites exist everywhere in life – day-night, hot-cold, loud-quiet. The poem encourages us to observe these contrasts and enjoy the variety in the world.

questions.question: Write about how comparisons make poetry fun and memorable. (Insight 155)
questions.answer: By linking objects like oxen, elves, mittens and caves with everyday qualities, the poem turns comparisons into playful word pictures that readers remember easily.

questions.question: Write about how comparisons make poetry fun and memorable. (Insight 195)
questions.answer: By linking objects like oxen, elves, mittens and caves with everyday qualities, the poem turns comparisons into playful word pictures that readers remember easily.

questions.question: Explain how the poem uses opposites to create strong imagery. (Insight 196)
questions.answer: Every line presents a pair of ideas that are far apart such as fast-slow or dry-wet. These opposites give the reader a strong sense of contrast and make everyday things exciting.

questions.question: Describe why similes help readers imagine things more clearly. (Insight 197)
questions.answer: Similes use familiar objects to describe unfamiliar or strong feelings. By saying 'strong as an ox', readers immediately understand the meaning without long explanations.

questions.question: How does the poet move from size and shape to sound and strength? (Insight 198)
questions.answer: The poem begins with size and speed, moves into taste, sound and strength, and ends with light-dark contrasts, showing many types of properties we can compare.

questions.question: Discuss why the poem says 'the world is full of opposites'. (Insight 199)
questions.answer: Opposites exist everywhere in life – day-night, hot-cold, loud-quiet. The poem encourages us to observe these contrasts and enjoy the variety in the world.

questions.question: Write about how comparisons make poetry fun and memorable. (Insight 200)
questions.answer: By linking objects like oxen, elves, mittens and caves with everyday qualities, the poem turns comparisons into playful word pictures that readers remember easily.
